content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include new definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." These definitions clarify the criteria for entities and individuals falling under these categories. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include new definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser," specifying criteria for entities falling under these categories, including assets under management and public representation as an investment adviser in the United States. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 has been amended to include new definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser," specifying criteria for entities falling under these categories. SEC. 3 eliminates the private adviser exemption and provides limited exemptions for foreign private fund advisers and limited intrastate exemptions. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include new definitions for "private fund" and "foreign private fund adviser." The amendment specifies criteria for entities falling under these categories, eliminating the private adviser exemption and providing limited exemptions for foreign private fund advisers and limited intrastate exemptions. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exemptions for certain investment advisers, such as those advising small business investment companies or entities related to them. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exemptions for certain investment advisers, such as those advising small business investment companies or entities related to them. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to authorize the Commission to require registered investment advisers to maintain records and file reports on private funds for investor protection and systemic risk assessment in consultation with the Federal Reserve System. The Commission can require registered investment advisers to provide reports on private funds to the Federal Reserve System and other entities with systemic risk responsibility. The reports must include information on assets under management and leverage usage. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report on various risk exposures, trading positions, practices, and additional information deemed necessary for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Different reporting requirements may be set based on the public interest and potential systemic risk contributions. Private fund advisers must adhere to different reporting requirements based on the types or sizes of private funds they advise. They are also mandated to maintain records of private funds for specified periods for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. These records are subject to periodic examinations by the Commission. Private fund advisers are required to maintain records of private funds for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission may conduct periodic examinations and request copies of records from registered investment advisers without undue effort. The Commission shares reports with the Federal Reserve System and other entities with systemic risk responsibility. Private fund advisers must provide reports, records, and documents to investors, prospective investors, counterparties, and creditors of private funds. The information obtained by the Board or other entities from the Commission for assessing systemic risk must be kept confidential. Private fund advisers must provide reports, records, and documents to investors, counterparties, and creditors as required by the Commission. The Commission is not obligated to disclose any reports or information filed under this subsection, ensuring confidentiality. The organization requesting the report or information must be within the jurisdiction or complying with a court order. This paragraph is considered a statute under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to eliminate a disclosure provision and provide an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with the requirement to maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION OF AND REPORTING BY CERTAIN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. These advisers must maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. The Commission will consider the size, governance, and investment strategy of mid-sized private funds to determine if they pose systemic risk. Registration and examination procedures for investment advisers of such funds will be based on the level of systemic risk they pose. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make, amend, and rescind rules and regulations necessary for its functions. This includes classifying persons and matters based on factors like size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk potential. The Commission is granted authority to make rules and regulations under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, including classifying persons and matters based on various factors. This includes addressing systemic risk potential and prescribing different requirements for different classes of persons or matters. Within 12 months of the Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009, the Reserve System and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission will jointly establish rules for reports to be filed by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to evaluate the annual costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements under the Act. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period. The Securities and Exchange Commission will allow advisers to register before the effective date. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require the Commission to adjust for inflation every 5 years any dollar amount test used in making determinations under this subsection. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
